resources.string: Deep Space Scouting App
@string/app_name
Endgame
Connect over Bluetooth
Your data have errors.
Bluetooth not connected.
This device is not connected to bluetooth. The data you submit will be stored locally, but not sent to the scouting laptop.\nWould you like to connect now?
Bluetooth Connected
Bluetooth has successfully connected to %1$s
Bluetooth submission failed.
Please talk to Telon, Carter, or other scouting leader
Bluetooth Error

An error occurred connecting to Bluetooth.\nPlease check that Bluetooth is enabled on this device, that the server is running on the scouting computer, and that you have selected that computer from the dropdown. Then try connecting again by clicking the Bluetooth icon in the top corner.\nIf errors persist, please get Carter for help.
Okay
Connect
Submit anyway
Cancel
Help

Welcome to the 449 Blair Robot Project Deep Space Scouting App!
For each match, you will be assigned a team to scout by your scouting leader. Watch this robot closely throughout the match, and record what they do.
To start, enter the basic information, like your name, the team you are scouting, etc. When the match starts, click the 'Start Match' button at the bottom to move to the Sandstorm period. When Sandstorm ends, move onto Teleop, then Endgame, then General. When you have all the data entered, click submit to submit your data and move on to the next match. Once you submit, you cannot go back and edit that data.
On many questions you will see a ? icon. Click this to get more information about that field
If you need more help with something, don't hesitate to ask a scouting leader.
Please talk to a scouting leader for help.
If the team\'s robot is not on the field for this match, select the box.

Each time the robot you are watching places a game piece, record it here. Click a square once to place a hatch, twice for a cargo, and three times if they place both. A fourth click will clear it.
The top of the grid represents the alliance station wall, with the top two boxes being the two cargo bays the point toward the drivers. The center group (2x4) is the cargo ship in the center of the field. The side groups (3x2) are the rockets, with the top of the rocket on the edge of the screen, and the bottom close to the center.
Feel free to rotate the screen so it lines up with the field.
Please only record pieces placed by YOUR robot, and INCLUDE those placed in the Sandstorm period
Each time your robot drops a game piece, for any reason (including if they are trying to place it and miss), please record it here by clicking the + button.
What HAB level did the robot start on?\nThe low base with a small ramp is level 1, the two short platforms about 6 inches above that is level 2.

If the robot moved and made it off of the HAB platform onto the carpet DURING SANDSTORM, check this box.\n(You may be familiar with \'Moved Forward\' or \'Crossed Line\' from past games - this is the same idea)
If the robot successfully placed their preloaded game piece DURING SANDSTORM check this box.
If the robot picked up and placed another game piece DURING SANDSTORM select the game piece that they placed. Otherwise, select "No" (or leave the item blank).
What HAB level (1 is the bottom platform, 2 is either of the two middle platforms, 3 is the highest platform) did they attempt to climb to?\n

Did the robot climb successfully? A successful climb has the robot reach and stay at the level they attempted. If no climb was attempted, simply put N/A (or leave it blank). A level 1 climb (the base platform) does count as a climb.

At the end of the match, what level was the robot at? (1 is the bottom platform, 2 is either of the two middle platforms, 3 is the highest platform)\nTo be a legal climb, the robot must be fully supported only by things at or above the level they have climbed to, and their bumpers must be above the level.\nIf, for example, a robot tries a level 3 climb, but they are supported by the side of the platform, above the height of level 2, this would count as a level 2 climb.

If the robot completed a level 2 or 3 climb, approximately how long did they spend, from the time they drove onto level 1 to the time they were stable and supported only by the level they are climbing to, with bumpers above that level.

Was the robot dead during the match?\nA dead robot is a robot that is just sitting on the field, unable to move.\nHalf dead is being dead for part (>~50%) of the match. Broken is ther\'re still moving, but something is clearly wrong. Dead means they were dead for all or almost all of the match.

If the robot attempted defense, select this box.\nThis is not a judgement of the quality of their defense, if they ever crossed the middle of the field with the intent to get in the way of the opposing alliance, that counts as an attempt at defense even if it was useless.
